newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn calls on SPD to resume tax reform talks.
newsitem.headline: Bonn calls on SPD to resume tax reform talks.

text.p: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU) on Thursday again urged opposition Social Democrats (SPD) to resume tax reform negotiations now that the coal subsidies issue has been successfully resolved.
CDU general secretary Peter Hintze, echoing a call made by Kohl himself on Wednesday, said the SPD no longer had any reason to avoid the tax reform talks.
The SPD boycotted a round of tax talks slated for last Saturday in protest against the government's plan to curtail coal subsidies.
SPD leaders have said they are prepared to resume the tax talks, but no date has been set.
Finance Minister Theo Waigel's comprehensive tax reform, including 30 billion marks in net tax cuts, is aimed at boosting jobs and investment.

The SPD supports most elements of the plan, but has urged that the launch date be moved up to 1998. The talks are aimed at ironing out differences over details such as the top tax rate and proposed taxes on night- and holiday shifts.
